Title: Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority members Martha Williams, Carol Brice, and Ursula Murrell at a sorority event, Los Angeles, 1935-1950
AltTitle.other: Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority
Description.note: Group photograph of five women (left to right): (2) Martha Williams, (3) Carol Brice, (4) Ursula Murrell standing in front of a curtain decorated with the AKA symbol at an Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority event. |~|Alpha Kappa Alpha (ΑΚΑ) is a Greek-lettered sorority, the first established by African-American college women on January 15, 1908 at Howard University. The membership is for college-educated women.  |~|Ursula Pruitt Murrell received a BA and MA in education from USC and was a music teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District for 30 years. A member of several civic, cultural and charitable organizations, she was known for her involvement in civic work.   |~|Carol Brice was an American contralto. She studied at Palmer Memorial Institute, Talladega College in Talladega, Alabama (BA, 1939), and the Juilliard School of Music (1939-1943). She attracted considerable attention for her role in a production of The Hot Mikado at the New York World's Fair (1939), where she worked with Bill "Bojangles" Robinson. Brice made her recital debut in 1943, that year becoming the first African-American to win the Walter Naumburg Award. Her concerts often featured the piano accompaniment of her brother, Jonathan Brice.|~|Martha Williams was a member of the Los Angeles branch of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority. She was also a participant in civic clubs.
Description.caption: Photographer's stamp on back: Gro M. Cutler, Jr. / Commercial, Portrait and Photo Arts / Photography / Phone AD. 11407 * 2710 Griffith Ave. / Los Angeles 11 Calif. Title: Pi Sigma Alpha Honorary Society page in the El Rodeo yearbook, 1930
AltTitle.other: Pi Sigma Alpha, National Honorary Political Science fraternity USC
Description.note: Portraits of members of the PI SIGMA ALPHA National Honorary Political Science Society, including  Edwin L. Jefferson (top row, center) in the University of Southern California El Rodeo yearbook, page 420.|~|Pi Sigma Alpha (ΠΣΑ or PSA), the National Political Science Honor Society, is an honor society for college and university students of political science in the United States. The first chapter of Pi Sigma Alpha was founded in 1920 at the University of Texas at Austin.|~|Edwin Lucius Jefferson was a 1931 graduate of the University of Southern California Law School. He was the first African American judge west of the Mississippi when he was appointed to the L.A. Municipal Court in 1941, and the first African American Justice for the California 2nd Appellate Court of Appeals. Jefferson was a civic leader, who in 1943 served on a committee to improve the housing situation for minorities in Los Angeles.
Description.caption: Captions on page: PI SIGMA ALPHA / National Honorary Political Science. Joseph Dubin President, Faculty: Dr. O. W. E. Cook, Dr. J. Eugene Harley, Dr. Roy Malcolm. Honorary: Dr. Rufus B. von Kleinsmid, Dean Justin Miller, Alan Nicholas, Dr. Henry C. Niese, Prof. J. Pheffner. Active Members: Russell Behrens, Charles Cook, Joseph S. Dubin, George Henderson, Edwin L. Jefferson, Louise Mitchell, George Sample, Hynie Smith, Edwin Talmadge, Herman Teplesky, K. S. Vandergriff, Sidney Wiener, Charles Wright. [Portrait caption:] Behrens, Jefferson, Henderson, Mitchell, Smith, Talmadge.

Title: Members of the Faben Phi Fraternity at a formal dance at Blanchard Music Hall, Los Angeles, 1912
AltTitle.other: First Annual Formal Dance of the Faben Phi Fraternity
Description.note: Group portrait of young African American men and women in formal dress at Blanchard Music Hall for the first Annual Formal Dance of the Faben Phi fraternity. Mamie White is in the back row on the left side of the left window. The woman to the left of Mamie is labelled "Nellie" or "Nelle." Musicians are visible in the back of the group on the left, including a man with a bass. There is a Christmas tree in the back on the left (although the date written on the back of the photo is April 8, 1912). |~|Mamie Virginia Cunningham White was the first African American clerk in the Los Angeles Post Office. |~|The Blanchard Music Hall was opened in 1899 (233 S. Broadway). Originally, this was a second floor hall with the Bartlett Music Store occupying the main floor. The building was also known as the H. Newmark Building. The venue was used for chamber music concerts and other programs. Later a banquet hall and an Assembly Hall was added to the building. There was also space in the Music and Art Building for studios musicians and artists as well as a fourth floor art gallery.
Description.caption: Written on front of photo: Mamie White (back row, forth from right), Nell (back center) Nell (?). Written on back of photo: M. Matthews who has given the Calif. Afro-American Museum a large mounted blow-up of this photo. April 8,1912 First Annual Formal Dance at Blanchard Hall of the Faben (?) Phi Fraternity.
Series: Daily Life in Black Los Angeles and California, 1885-1980
Sub-series: Social clubs, Greek societies, Community Organizations

Title: Betty Hill is honored for her contributions to Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, 1955
AltTitle.other: Prominent Los Angeles clubwomen and civil rights activists
Description.note: Betty Hill holds an award certificate with 11 people standing with her, including Los Angeles Councilman Kenneth Hahn (back row, wearing glasses).  |~|Betty Hill, dubbed by the Los Angeles Sentinel the "Mother of Negro Political Leaders," founded the Women's Republican Study Club (later the Women's Political Study Club) in Los Angeles in 1929. Her many causes included fighting Jim Crow in Los Angeles hospitals and public swimming pools, abolishing separate civil service lists for African American school teachers, and getting the Board of Education to approve a child care center program. Hill was married to Sgt. Abraham Hill.|~|Kenneth Hahn (1920–1997) was a member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors for forty years, from 1952 to 1992. Hahn was on the Los Angeles City Council from 1947 to 1952. He was an ardent supporter of civil rights throughout the 1960s, and met Martin Luther King, Jr. in 1961.
Description.caption: Typescript on front of award: The People of the County of Los Angeles in Appreciation of the dedicated, unselfish, and untiring efforts of Mrs. Betty Hill in civic and community affairs for the good of all people and especially for her leadership in all of the major improvements at Will Rogers Park including the fine new swimming pool.
Series: Daily Life in Black Los Angeles and California, 1885-1980
Sub-series: Social clubs, Greek societies, Community Organizations
Name.subject: Hill, Betty, 1876-1960|~|Hahn, Kenneth

Title: Announcement of the dedication of the new Southern area Boys' Club, Los Angeles, 1957
AltTitle.other: Boys Club
Description.note: Announcement of the dedication of the new Southern Area Boys Club with a photographic image of the building and the logo of the Boys Club organization. |~|The Roy W. Roberts, II - Watts / Willowbrook Boys & Girls Club opened 1957 in the community of Watts / Willowbrook. It was founded as a gift to the community from the Los Angeles Times Charities, Inc. and it was incorporated as Southern Area Boys Club. This organization was the first club to serve the south Los Angeles area. It is now named in memory of its long-time executive director of twenty-seven years, Roy W. Roberts.

Title: Samuel John Booth, mason and successful gold prospector, British Columbia, 1880-1900
AltTitle.other: Black Masons in Los Angeles
Description.note: Studio portrait of Samuel Booth, wearing regalia that might be masonic. |~|Samuel John Booth was a resident of Victoria, B.C., from c. 1858 to 1917. One of four black prospectors who formed a company to mine gold at Leechtown (Leech River) in 1864, he became quite prosperous. The regalia that he wears is probably American and may not even be masonic. It is not the style of regalia worn in the jurisdiction of British Columbia and there is no record of his membership in Grand Lodge records. There was also no masonic affiliation noted in his obituary. It is probable that he was a member of a Prince Hall lodge before he moved to Victoria. [http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/biography/booth_s/booth_s.html]
Description.caption: Written on Back of photo: Samuel Booth. Mason and gold seeker. See pp. 90, 148 "Go do some great thing: by Crawford Kilian.
Series: Daily Life in Black Los Angeles and California, 1885-1980

AltTitle.other: Black Masons in Los Angeles
Description.note: Photograph caption: Clinging to his beautiful engraved plaque, past master Monroe P. Parker beams with appreciation as he poses with members of Thomas Waller Lodge No. 49. Parker was presented the plaque for more than forty-three years of meritorious service to the organization. Pictured from left to right are James D. Jenkins, senior warden; Monroe Parker, honoree; Bernard Gray, past master; and Charles D. Fowlkes, worshipful master. (Los Angeles Sentinel, 21 Dec. 1967: D5)|~|Monroe Parker was a Baptist minister and a master at the Thomas Waller Masonic Lodge #49. |~|Bernard Gray was a realtor for Miracle Mortgage Service in Carson. He also served as an officer and reverend at  St. Philip’s Episcopal Church, and was a master at the Thomas Waller Masonic Lodge #49.|~|James D. Jenkins was the reverend of Phillip's Chapel located at 1500 E. 109th St.

Title: Paul Howard, Bernard Gray, Monroe Parker, Richard Hunt and Frank White, past masters of the masons, Los Angeles, 1967
AltTitle.other: Black Masons in Los Angeles
Description.note: Group photograph of members of  members of Thomas Waller Lodge No. 49 gathered to honor Monroe P. Parker, who holds his plaque. From left: Paul Howard, Bernard Gray, Monroe Parker, Richard Hunt, and Frank White.|~|Paul Howard was a top rated jazz saxophonist. For over 30 years he was a member of the American Federation of Musicians, Local #767. He was advanced to the role of Treasurer of the Union’s Credit Union.|~|Bernard Gray was a Past Master at the Thomas Waller Masonic Lodge #49. He also was an officer, and reverend at St. Philip’s Episcopal Church. Gray worked as a Realtor for Miracle Mortgage Service, Inc. in Carson, California.
Description.caption: Written on back of photo: 1970 Past Masters of different lodges-Delta, Holland & Thomas Waller. From left: Paul Howard, Bernard Gray, Monroe Parker, Richard Hunt and Frank White. [occasion mis-identified]

Title: Five Prince Hall Freemasonry Masonic Lodges in California, including Los Angeles, Riverside, San Diego, Pasadena, and San Francisco, 1940-1989
AltTitle.other: Black Masons in Los Angeles
Description.note: Photographic montage with images of five Prince Hall Masonic lodges in California, each one with a distinctive architectural style: Prince Hall Masonic Temple (1050 E. 50th St., Los Angeles), Orange Valley Lodge Hall (2931 12th St, Riverside), Fidelity Lodge Hall, (3007 Logan Ave, San Diego), Hannibal Lodge Hall (2804 Bush Street San Francisco), and Masonic Hall, Pasadena.|~|Prince Hall Freemasonry is a branch of North American Freemasonry founded by Prince Hall, and is composed predominantly of African Americans.
